skills.name: Understand that an enlargement of a shape does not change the size of angles

explanations.A: For Tom’s statement, picture the base length being the longest side (11cm). Could the other two sides be 10cm and 2cm? Yes they could, because in total they are longer than the base side. However this shows us that Katie’s lengths would not form a triangle as 5 ＋ 3 is equal to 8. If the 5 and 3 started from either end of the 8cm line they would only meet if they formed a perfectly straight line. In which case we would have a line, not a triangle.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try drawing some diagrams to help you. What would happen if the 2 shorter sides added to make the same length as the longest side?
explanations.C: Not quite. Try drawing some diagrams to help you. What would happen if the 2 shorter sides added to make the same length as the longest side?
explanations.D: Not quite. Try drawing some diagrams to help you. It does seem strange to have a 2cm length between two much longer sides, but is it impossible?

explanations.A: Not quite. If I know 2 side lengths of a triangle does that mean there is only one option for the third length? Try holding two pens together as the two sides and investigating what happens when you change the angle between them.
explanations.B: You do not need a protractor to construct some types of triangles. What instrument could you use instead?
explanations.C: Not quite. If I know 2 side lengths of a triangle does that mean there is only one option for the third length? Try holding two pens together as the two sides and investigating what happens when you change the angle between them.
explanations.D: Jo’s statement is incorrect: three pieces of information are needed in order to construct a triangle. If only 2 side lengths are given, then the angle between these sides is also necessary in order to define the length of the third side. Paul’s statement is incorrect because a compass can be used to construct a triangle, providing the lengths of all 3 sides have been given.

explanations.A: The two triangles are similar because the triangles have two pairs of angles that are equal (although one triangle has been rotated compared to the other). So we know that angle k must equal 60°. Alternatively, in the smaller triangle, we know that angles in a triangle add to 180°, so k = 180 − (75 ＋ 45) = 60°.
explanations.B: I think you have doubled the angle. Look at the other 2 angles in the smaller triangle. What do angles in a triangle add up to?
explanations.C: I think you have halved the angle because the side length has been halved. Look at the other 2 angles in the smaller triangle. What do angles in a triangle add up to?
explanations.D: Because the 2 angles either side of our given length are the same (45 and 75) then we have a pair of similar triangles. Which angle would correspond to 'k' on the larger triangle?

explanations.A: I think you have doubled the angle. Look at the other 2 angles in the smaller triangle. What do angles in a triangle add up to?
explanations.B: I think you have halved the angle because the side length has been halved. Look at the other 2 angles in the smaller triangle. What do angles in a triangle add up to?
explanations.C: The two triangles are similar because the triangles have two pairs of angles that are equal (although one triangle has been rotated compared to the other). So we know that angle p must equal 60°. Alternatively, in the smaller triangle, we know that angles in a triangle add to 180°, so p = 180 − (70 ＋ 50) = 60°.
explanations.D: Because the 2 angles either side of our given length are the same (50 and 70) then we have a pair of similar triangles. Which angle would correspond to 'p' on the larger triangle?

explanations.A: How would the 8cm and 6cm lengths be found?
explanations.B: How did we get the 39° angle?
explanations.C: The ruler measured the lengths and drew the straight lines. The protractor made the angle of 39°. The compass was set to 6cm to create the third side.
explanations.D: How was the 6cm side found? What instrument made the blue curved line?

explanations.A: How will you measure the 12cm and 7cm sides? Think about where they are in relation to the 52° angle.
explanations.B: How will you measure the 52° angle? Think about where it is in relation to the 7cm and 12cm sides.
explanations.C: Think about where the angle is, in relation to the two sides. How can you draw the third side?
explanations.D: Because our known side lengths are both next to the given angle, we can just join the ends to draw the third side.

explanations.A: How would the 8cm and 6cm lengths be found?
explanations.B: How did we get the 39° angle?
explanations.C: Think about where the angle is, in relation to the two known side lengths. How can you draw the third side?
explanations.D: The ruler measured the lengths and drew the straight lines. The protractor made the angle of 39°. As our known side lengths are both next to the given angle, we can just join the ends to draw the third side.

explanations.A: I think you might have doubled the 15cm side. This will be longer than the diagonal we are interested in. Try to cosntruct an accurate drawing of this shape and measure the missing diagonal.
explanations.B: Not quite. You might have estimated. Try to construct an accurate drawing of this shape, starting with your base line and then using your compasses at either end, set to 15cm. If they won't stretch this far then you might have to use a scale.
explanations.C: This is the length of the diagonal we have been given. The other diagonal will not necessarily be the same length. Construct an accurate copy of this shape and measure the missing diagonal.
explanations.D: To construct this shape we start with our base line of 24cm. We then place our compasses at either end of the line, set to a width of 15cm and draw arcs above and below the line. Where they intersect gives us the final two vertices of our shape. If you measure the distance between these vertices we will get 18cm.

explanations.A: To construct this shape we start with our base line of 16cm. We then place our compasses at either end of the line, set to a width of 10cm and draw arcs to the left and right of the line. Where they intersect gives us the final two vertices of our shape. If you measure the distance between these vertices we will get 12cm.
explanations.B: This is the length of the diagonal we have been given. The other diagonal will not necessarily be the same length. Construct an accurate copy of this shape and measure the missing diagonal.
explanations.C: Not quite. This is half the length of the existing diagonal. In order to find the length of the missing diagonal we have to construct an accurate drawing of this shape. Start by drawing the central line and then use your compasses either end, set to 10cm.
explanations.D: Not quite. This is one of the side lengths. In order to find the length of the missing diagonal we have to construct an accurate drawing of this shape. Start by drawing the central line and then use your compasses either end, set to 10cm.
